sp.p: Lost dayes can never be recalled. Time steals away, a● thou art a stealer of time. See now how thou hast i● croached vpon my pretious time, whilst I heare a● speake, with such a canker of good houres. Awa● away.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: You bid me away, because you dare not play wi● mee.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Dost thou dare me thou elfe? I will.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p:
I know you'le venture no money, nor points.
must play with you for nothing. Come on therefore at hide and seeke, o● blinde man buffe.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Come, I will once boy it againe at either for a crash

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Why then at bl●ndman buffe you shall bee first blinded.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Nay sir boy, if you challenge and choose the game too, you must be first blinded. But what tooles haue wee?

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Borrow one of these Gentlewomens maskes:

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Nay then you will looke through the holes. Will you gull me so?

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: If I once looke through the holes, then say Ludio is set in the Pillo●y. but rather then want ●ew, here take my ga●ter, and tye my sachell about my face.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: O with what wicked bumbast i● his sachell slust? I thought it was not true begotten bookes, that made the belly of it swell so bigge.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: It has cast calfe now. You must tye mee to these winckers.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I had rather tye thee to one of our schoole posts, or hang our great dic●ary at thy heele, for a clogge to keepe thee from gadding to play.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Talke not to me of Dick snary, nor Richard-sna|ry; I care not how little I come neare them. But sir you must haue this Morice-bell tied to your point, that I may heare where you goe. Else you will haue too much oddes of me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Will you make me act hobby horse, or Master Gin|gle? For once I will.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Now that is on, come and tye me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: So, you are tyed, now I must turne you about thrice. Sic deluditur Ludre. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p:
I doe not heare the bell. Lauriger stands still I
doubt. Nay gentle playfellow, you must stirre vp and downe, ●e we shall haue no sport.

sp.speaker: Sirea.
sp.p: I Hope to finde more game here. O yonder's a ●h 〈◊〉. I think he is caught in our net already. So, so, Verily Cup● hath blinded him for our purpose.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: O I haue him. I haue him. But where is your bell? vnty● me now 〈◊〉 your 〈◊〉 to be blinded O what ha●d 〈◊〉 Vndow me, vndoe me.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.p: I haue but the vn●oing of many in my dayes. But I 〈◊〉 met with so forward a guest, that would begge hi● owne vndoing.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: I haue ouer come it now. What now? Hee turn'd to Shee? 〈◊〉Lauriger, me thinkes your lookes are grown very long on the sodain. Has he seru'd me thus?

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.p: How well art thou seru●d, when such a Nimph is at thy seruice?

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: It tho● be at my seruice, s●ake thy silken coate, and golden ●and, against my garters and hat. Lift who shall deale.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.p: Itell thee, I vse little plaine dealing. I must shuffle and cut too.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Both? Nay that's against law.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.p: Yet will i deale plainely with thee. I haue neither skill nor minde to play with thee.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Can any sweet Nimph be a stranger to Ludio? I haue heard that Nimphs loue to play at more games then I know.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.p: I doe not refuse, because thou art a stranger, but be|cause thou art our friend; Thou a●t ours already. What need wee spend bi●me vpon those wanton sparrowes, that are in our cage already? S●t 〈◊〉Ludio, thou art a member of our fa●il Queene He done gets good acces●e by thee. Goe on with all thy thrifty wares to get in more letters vp in our trade. Goe to sir G●biano, make him pay for thy acquain|tance.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Gentle goldilockes. I would doe so, but that I am now imployed against my woont in studying ●n ora|tion to saue my head from a blow, which Apollos vi|sitation may now bring vpon me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: NOuice, you know you must appeare too.

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: I haue cited him according to law.

sp.speaker: N●u.
sp.p: What is the matter, thinke you?

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: I heard a bird sing (hearke in your eare) that theres an accusation against you for misspending your time with Captaine Complement.

sp.speaker: N●.
sp.p: I doe but as others doe. I am not alone.

sp.speaker: ●nd.
sp.p: What strange guest is yon? A female I thinke. Who but Siren that has made such turmoiles here o● late. Pr●co haue you cited ●er?

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p:
Shee's in my ●owle, I'me glad I haue met with her. Dame Siren, thou art ●ndited by the name of Siren for subuerting Apollos subiects; You must along with mee, and appeare to answer such matters
as shall be obiected against you, on the behalfe of our Soueraigne Lord Apollo.

sp.speaker: Siren.
sp.p: Thou arrest me, who haue arrested thy betters? I tell thee, I will be there. I haue good friends in A|pollos Court. I will not be hired to tarry away. But be|fore I goe, I must deliuer a message to you from a great goddesse.

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: A goddesse to mee?

sp.speaker: Siren.
sp.p: I●o thee, and thee, and to you all.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Say what thou must, or canst.

sp.speaker: Siren.
sp.l: Hedone, Queene Hedone, sweet Hedone,
Dame natures care, and noblest birth,
The i●y, and crowne of heauen, and earth,
The aime, and center of desire,
The fuell of most sacred fire,
By me, and this, and this
She sends you all her blisse.
Among the gods she hath her pla●e,
They all stand gazing on her face.
The clouds d● from her presence flye,
'Tis sunshine where she casts her eye.
Where are she treads on earth below,
A rose or ●illy vp doth grow.
Her breath a gale of spi● brings:
Mute are the Muses when she sings.
What ere she touches turnes to N●ar,
What man, but can, and must affect her?
No heart so hard, but needes must melt,
When once her kindely warmth is felt.
She, she vouchsafe, to call you to her,
And wooing prayes you now to wooe her.
By study soone, fresh youth doth breake,
The faire grow foule, the strong grow weake:
Leaue leaue this musing bookish trade:
Inioy your selues before youth fade.
Time must be gone,
Old age creepes on.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: She puts her message home, me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: I haue arrested her; and I thinke shee will ar|rest vs.

sp.speaker: Nouice.
sp.p: I like her song well, I'le get a coppy of it. If A|pollo giue me leaue, I will haue more acquaintance with her. Me thinkes this Siren would make a good wife for my Master, Captaine Complement, and so she shall be my Mistresse. O faire Hedone, sweet honey Hedone, more sweet then Marmalet, or Quidony.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Away thou glosing slatterer. Wee are no game for thee. Let vs about our businesse. Praeco doe your office, carry her away. Let her chant this song before Apollo. The Muses will out-sing her, and teare her s●earing lockes. I will goe cite Slug. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: GEntle sir Gingle, the flowre of my schoole, re|turne my thankes to the honourable Dame Indulgence thy high deseruing Mother, for the glitte|ring token the sent me. I shall deserue it in my readi|nesse to accomplish thee. But where ended we yester|day?

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: You were instructing me how to salute a Lady, or so, if she had a Monkey, or so, and wept, or so.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: This is but so, so.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: In case you finde a Lady weeping and ●ournfull, for that her M●nkey is sicke of the mum●●, 〈◊〉 say.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Faire ●ady weepe not for your Monkey.

sp.speaker: Comp
sp.p: This is bare and vulgar. Rather ●sh your salutation thus. 〈◊〉〈◊〉 Clarid●na.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: ●t as can be. T● is Clarid●na was courted by the Knight of the sunne. My Mother has ●ad that booke to me. Si● your s●le is very h●h and lo●.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Ves sir, my master and I haue gone ouer many ●s high a stile, when we went to robbe orchards for our dinners.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Twise d●ble worthy dubbed Maddaine—

sp.speaker: Giag.
sp.p: Twise d●ble dubbed. What doth shee weare a double●〈◊〉 Ladies ●e to weare doublets now?

sp.speaker: Cyn●.
sp.p: You vnde stand not. There was of late yeeres a sashion, when h● vir, & hic mulier were in request. But gentle Gingle, though thou dost stand vnder me, yet thou dost not vnderstand me. Twise doubly be|cause she hath two 〈◊〉 to her honour. The full a title of law which shee hath from ●et ●u band who was dubbed Knight with an vnbloody sword. The second The second What ●'st. h●m h●, the second. Oh I haue it, because the is rich● in cloathes then ●n ioynter. But proc● we in your approach.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Oh s● you haue wonderfully 〈◊〉●dme.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I haue wipe ●and cla●d the dull spectacle of thy intellect with the Nap● of my Comment.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Indeed now me thinks ●espye her clearely w● put a looking-glasse. But how should I forbid her to weep?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: To weepe? Madame I forbid the ba●es betweene you and s●ow.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I, the Knights name Sorrow?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Perhaps hee's a o●y knight, (like my master)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: What Imp. you are too nimble. Are you so saucy to step before me?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: (I was saine to step before him when we stole hens together, and he put me fir● into the henn-●oost.)

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Truely Captaine me thinkes Implement suggests very 〈◊〉 would willingly forbid those banes.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Forbidding banes? Away with this forbidding banes. It is a bane●ull ominous word, not besitting the wooing 〈◊〉. You shall mould all vp in the sine pulle past of poetry thus.
Twice double worthy dubbed Madame,
Whose vertues not the longest tongue can sadome.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I thinke La●es garments are measured by th'●ll and by the yard, but measuring their vertues by the ●adome, I neuer heard o● before.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Twice double worthy dubbed Madame, Whose long tongue no man can sadome.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: O dismall. O dangerous! Take heed of stumbling so with your tongue when you speake of female tongues. Whose vertues not the longest tongue can fadome.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Whose vertues not the longest tongue can fadome.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Right and streight. Then on.
Souse not thy glittering globy eyne
In d eary teary salt sea brine.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Globy eyne? What's that?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Kno●st thou not what globy is? I perceiue then thou a● no traueller, thou hast not (as I haue done) trauelled about the globe of the earth. Know'st not what eyne be? I see thou art no Poet, thou hast neuer read Chau●r. Hast thou neuer heard of eyne tw●ine?

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Souse not. This word will not downe with me.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: M^r. Gingles queasie slomacke cannot disgest souse.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: The Lady will thinke, I vse to conuerse with Tripe|wiues, if I talke to her of souse.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: M^r you once courted a sousing Dame, (a fulsome Kitchinwench.)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Peace thou squeaking pigge; or else the bandogs of these hands shall lugge thy lagging eares. Souse not thy globyeyne. I tell thee this is not such as it is vulgar|ly taken. It is not a butcherly word, it is not descended from the Tripe wife, nor hath it affinity with the fryingpan.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Nor did it euer hang cheeke by iole with a blacke pudding.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Marke the Philosophy of the phrase. The roaring dashing element, the sea is salt, and brine is salt, and trickling teares are s●lt.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: And P. I. S. is salt.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.p: The sea, the bryne, the teares, the teares, the bryne, the sea. Why may they not all three thus da|shing, soaking, soucing lye? It is a martiall word. I vse it often my selfe, I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I too often when you tell me you'le giue me a souse on the eare.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Souse not, &c. Fit. wondrous fit, as my persumed gloue for my sweethand. It shee wept for sorrow be|fore, I shall now make her weepe for ioy to heare this eloquence.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: But my Masters, you leaue the poore Monkey too long in distresse. Heelle dye o'th Mumpes, vnlesse we relieue him the sooner.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: 'Tis true. Pray goe on. I am to say your Monkey will recouer. Master Prompter doe your part.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Then thus. Your soure leg'd, two-leg'd, Man|imitating, two-handed, long-tayled play fellow, shall be readuanced to his pristine integrity of limbs.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: He had need put in sound of winde and limb, for the Mumps lay siege to his throate, and breed more danger to his weazand, then to his tenne bones.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Two-foot, foure-foot? how can that be? Hath hee sixe feet?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Sixe feet? sixe to one my Master puts the tricke of the louse vpon him. I haue knowne when hee has blowne them in a quill vpon better men this this.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Thou art not worthy to be numbred among the two-footed, but rather art to bee imbased vnto the foure-footed. If thou dost not vnderstand how Apes and Monkeyes are two-leg'd and two-handed; some|time they creepe on all foure. Imp. shew him how, sometime they stalke on tiptoe. Thus.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: If I had bin an Ape I should haue climed plum|trees brauely.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Let me see how you can imitate this.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Sometime they trace on all foure thus.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Sometime they ride vpon a mastiffe dogge thus. I want nothing now but my whippe to keepe this Lol|lard hound in awe.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Come off Imp. Enough of this. We will send him hereafter for instruction to Paris Garden, where hee shall learne not onely Apetrickes, but the whipping o● blinde Beares.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Paris Garden? O sin●l Paris they say is a ●ne Ci|ty in France. I am glad he will send mee thither. No man can be a compleat Gentleman till he haue learnt their cringes and crinkling i'th hams: which is in ex|cellent request to the heauens now adayes.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Good sir, I hope my selfe, and such men of worth as I, haue transported thence already plentifull loads of this French ware, that you shall saue the la|bour and cost of liuing there at their deare Ordina|ries and pretious dancing-schooles, you must there|fore in your stipend to me allow me, for that which I spent among Counts, Nobles, Knights and Monsiers there; sometime it'h fiue pound Ordinary, I tell you.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: An horrible profitable lye My Master ne're dyn'd there but with O●llers and Vintners boyes.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I tell you it cost me soure Nobles to the Vsher of the dancing schoole to learne one tricke, which they cal Le Tourne fuseau It wheeles a man about, as a boy does a stone in a ho●pe, and makes him appeare as round and vniforme, as a loyne●s turn'd bed post.

sp.speaker: Gins.
sp.p: I pray you learne me that whi● legig tricke.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: You are not come to that. Be not so hasty, you are yet but in the Rudiments, and to tell you plaine, you must refund to me some charge for other proficiency before we aspire so high.
There was another vaulting tricke called the ●ur.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: The base vulgar in English call it the hoister.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: It lifts a man vp til● he grow lesse and lesse like a Hawke after a Heron. Shaw. It cost me. Let me see.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: how much?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Vpon mine honour thirty Crownes.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I thinke it was but twenty.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: By your leaue master, I know better then you. Doe not I keepe your Count Booke? I'me sure 'twa● that weeke that you bought the Iewellers rich Diamond that was refused by so many Nobles. They could not reach the price of it.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: O it was the late Queene Mothers Iewell. Thou didstill thou forgetfull brat to leaue it behinde. I should haue worne it at this publike show. All Parnos|sus would haue admired it.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Master, you lost the key of your Cabinet. I durst not breake it ope (The diuell a Iewell we haue, but one that was bought of a Pedlar, and in the Country Townes he makes a great show with it at Beare. bai|tings, but in such ciuill places as this is, he durst not be seene with it.)

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I pray you when I am i'th humour of buying Iew|els, let me haue the refusall of it.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Thou shalt, because thou art an ingenious Gen|tleman 〈◊〉Imp. Remember to set downe a caueat in the Margent of my Inuentary, that no man el●e ●y so much as looke on it or haue any price set of it.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: M●ster Gingle I pray you pay me ten groars foren|tring this Caueat in mine ●ffice. My see my see sir.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Come to me at my lod●〈◊〉, and I will lay ●alt on this birds ●yle dor feare o● flyingg away.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I tell you Master Gingle. It will goe neere to cost you the manner of Foolingham.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Let oakes and lands flye. I meane to gl●tter bright in Diamond▪ dearely dight.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: You must adde.
That men and dames may gaze, and say,
Wh●t 〈◊〉 is that, that glides along this way?

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: What starts is that, &c O excell● All the world could neuer haue furnisht me with such a Tutor.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Say rat er all the habitable circumference of this muddy masly earthy globe could not haue affoorded and suppeditated vnto me so melli●uous an Indoctri|nator, as is the curious Captaine Complement.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: O that I could by Metamorphasis be transformed into this eloquent man.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Thou hadst better bee transformed with Apuleius●o a golden Asse.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I tell thee I haue written a large booke of instru|ctions how a man should weare his cloaths, on which side his p●e should lye in his pocket, which ●ocking he should draw on first vpon ominous dayes.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Indeed 〈◊〉 I haue heard you often tell of a man that brake his legge because hee pul'd on his left stocking first on one of the dogge dayes.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I sirra, and there was another, that had the tooth|ach seuen yeeres after, because he pic●t his teeth with the south end of his picktooth, in stead of the north, while he was in his chamber meditating a discourse to be offred vp before a beny of Ladies.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Is there south and no●n a picktooth?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I, it was touched with a loadstone.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I would rather haue pickt my teeth with my knife thus, then haue runne into such a mischiefe.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: What say you? what doe you? doe you weare a knife about you?

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I'me sure it cost mee a Marke, and I got mine armes grauen vpon the blade, three hobby-horses or, prancing in a field▪ or, b●idled and sadled argent.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Then I must n●s tell you my minde. I hop'd well that you would proue vnder my hands, but now I doubt you are no Gentleman, I feare you le neuer proue fashionable, I will rather imploy my paines a|bout other my schollars who haue vowed neuer to weare kniues.
What? weare a knife. Nay I haue done with you.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Nay, good sir, I pray you doe not cast me off, I'le rather cast away this clownish toole.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I may take it vp and weare it. No knife can wound my gentry.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: We burne day light. I must hast, and muster vp my friends and aduocates to plead for mee in this Court. Sirra Imp. runne to Mistresse Gingle, tell her, now 'tis time.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I will be your Remembrancer to her: Shee shall protect you, else she is no mother for me.

sp.speaker: Geron with a forke on's necke.
sp.p: I Haue bin mending my hedges, which the scuruy boy Ludio broake downe. And now when I would rest at home, and take my nooning-nap, I must bee vexed with my sonne, my wretched sonne. They say that Apollo keepes visitation to day. I will lay my sonne at his Pallace gate, perhaps this feast day wee may get some fauour, some drop of his clemency. Exit.

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: IV. ge Rubbish What Iugge? bring away the loo|king gla●e. Thou dirty Rubbish, thy singers haue defiled the lace of my Cuffes. Will not cuffing a|bout the eares make you more cleanly?

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p: The lace is so thicke, that I was faine to tugge hard at it. I know not what can foule it, vnlesse the smoo|thing-iron cast a rusty colour through the paper

sp.speaker: Ind.
sp.p: Out vpon thee for an old rusty lyer. The glasse▪ Hold it on the other side. You know I doe not loue to behold that moule on this cheeke. Thou spitefull baggage, more yet on the left hand. Is that the left hand?

sp.speaker: Iug.
sp.p: Heere's my left hand.

sp.speaker: Ind.
sp.p:
I, but the other side is my left hand. You must con|forme
your eyes and hands to your▪ Mistresse, and for|get which is your owne right or left. Do's my Vaile hang in true proportion?

sp.speaker: Iug.
sp.p: I can say nothing ●or any portion, but in hangs iust behinde you.

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: Vnlesse I be set all in print, the Poeticall Mus● will make times on me, when they see mee in A● Iudgement Hall. But Iugge, what had my sonne to breakefast this morning?

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p: A Pullets wing.

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: That's not forsooth. What nothing else?

sp.speaker: Iug.
sp.p: Forsooth a piece of Pye too But so sooth Mistresse, if you giue me leaue, I'le tell you what they say o● him.

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: What? who? Why?

sp.speaker: Iug.
sp.p: Marry forsooth P●ponus, and others eke also d● say, if you feed him so much, that he will neuer p●u: a scholler.

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: Proue scholler? Doe they thinke my childe is so low borne as to be made a ●y scholler? Shall such a keene resin'd w●t be dul'd and imbased, by plodding on a booke? What is Philoponus but a Bookeworme, an Inckhorne squirt, a botching patcher of Latin shred● What is this learning, but a little gibberish in the tongue, a sheepish looke in the face, and pennilesse famine in the purse? I he more schollar a young man is, the lesse like to speed of a rich wife. I will haue my sonne the marke and wish of the most renowned Dames.

sp.speaker: Iug.
sp.p: I doe not so hate schollars, but that I could ●ne in my heart to ma●y Phil●us at a venture.

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p:
I will, as man●erly as I may, tell Apollo that it is an honour to his schoole, that such a one as my sonne was of it, though but for a tast of the Muses dish, a
gentle touch of the verge of their garment. I, but is my Coach ready?

sp.speaker: Iug.
sp.p: One of the horses is very vnruly, the Coachman. talkes like a rogue, and sayes that nothing but a wise will tame him.

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: This lewd horse-rubbers tongue must be tam'd I doubt he is three quarters drunke.

sp.speaker: Iug.
sp.p: That's no newes.

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: I must away, the houre runnes with swifter race then my horses. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus quartus. Scena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Geron and Retro his sonne.

sp.p: KEepe on thy way, dost thou not see? hold on that path. Seest thou not how my staffe doth wise thee the way? I thinke thou cam'st backward in|to the world, that now art dam'd to this crab-like pace. Shall I neuer be rid of this office? So: stand still Now me thinkes I see the portch of great Apollos temple. O great Apollo, if my sonne haue thus deser|ued to be punished, yet what hath guiltlesse Geron, what hath he offended?

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Tnou dost well to humble thy selfe before great Apollo. But why to pardon vs? Why me?

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: What sayest thou to thy Father?

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: What sayest thou? Was it my fault?

p.hi: Voy. tes. em. ta. ot. ih, a koob.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Did I set you 〈◊〉〈◊〉●high a booke? You were too proud of your 〈◊〉, and would needes slide ouer the ●udiments, and leape at first into an higher forme, then your capacity would reach vnto.

sp.speaker: Retro.
sp.p: 〈◊〉. rehtom. Im. ●thom.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Thy Mother, thy Mother. I, it is true, thy Mo|ther would needes haue it so. I must needs say 'twas her fault, not mine. She 〈◊〉 ioggd me, and told mee, that her Rowland was as good a schollar, as his Ma|ster, and that the 〈◊〉 est booke did best befit his ●gh 〈◊〉〈◊〉〈◊〉 now 〈◊〉 thy long long 〈◊〉●nance vnto me, then to thy two yeeres haue I bin 〈◊〉 at home. It grieues & g●ates m●e 〈◊〉〈◊〉〈◊〉 this backward language imposed by Apollos doome on my wretched childe. It wounds mine eyes to see these backward steps. And yet re|maines a 〈◊〉〈◊〉 for me,
sp.l: To be the scorne and by word of this pla●e.
Old Gerons ouer-forward childe
Retorted fo● his ●astinesse,
Is made the prou●〈◊〉 of these times.
And likened to soone ●ipe soone ●otten fruit▪
〈◊〉 how long time remaines yet vnexpir'd
〈◊〉 this vnnaturall preposterous taske?
〈◊〉 I, so, it is one whole liuelong yeere.
●ich thy poore father (spent with teares and grief)
●arce hopes now to ou●last. Alas
The candle of my dayes is almost spent,
It waueth in th● snufte, and little oyle
Is left to make it flame.
And yet alas too soone these blasts of sighes
Will puffe it out▪ ●ese teares will drowne it quite.

sp.speaker: Retro.
sp.p: Rethaf. reed. Rethaf.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: What sayest thou my deere sonne, too deere to me, that hast me cost so deepe a punishment.

sp.speaker: Ret.
sp.p: Tel. su. geb so. ol● pa.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Well What shall we begge of Apollo?

sp.speaker: Ret.
sp.p: Ot, nodrap. su. sibt. ●ey.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: To pardon this yeere to vs, and release thee? I feare thy wishes are farre larger then ou● hopes.

sp.speaker: Ret.
sp.p: Irr●m. ollopa.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Merry Apollo? I doubt his eares are stopt, and I haue heard the gods v●e not to recall their doomes, which they haue once pronounced.

sp.speaker: Ret.
sp.p: Keps. o● suesu●n.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: What? wouldest thou haue me speake to Musaeus Apollos Priest, to intercede for thee for this remission?

sp.speaker: Ret.
sp.p: Os ot. mih.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.l: IN good time here he comes forth.
But sonne I dare not approach to him.
O what a trembling reuerence doth possesse
My limbs, and all benums my chill cold blood,
When I behold his awefull grauity.
Let vs retire beside this shady tree
This mossy ban●ke will rest my weary limbs,
And giue me time to recollect my spirits.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Graue guide of ●ender youth, Interpreter
Of great Apollos lawes chiefe secretary
Vnto the learned Muses, all your words
Are lodged safe in this laborious breast.
Thinke your command's no sooner said then done▪

sp.speaker: Musaeus.
sp.l: Carefull Philoponus, I approue your paines
And haue already recommended you
Vnto Apollos selfe. O that the rest
Of those, that vndertake this worthy task●,
Pretending to the liberall sciences,
Could so acquit themselues.
But 〈◊〉 all seeing 〈◊〉 in circling round
About bot● Hemispheares of this large world,
Hath spy'd that some (O too too great a summe)
Haue s●ly crept within the verge and pa●
Of his dominions. In truth they strangers are,
Nay enemies and rebels to his lawes;
Yet would be counted Natiues of his schoole,
By them his tender plants corrupted are,
Distorted, brui●ed, hindred of their growth.
Thinke they that these ●oundations haue bin l●
These Cells erected, and those Temples dight
To harbour such foule el●es? Shall snorting sloa●
Thinke here to nestle, fixed to his bed,
As is the slow-pac'd snaile vnto his shell?
Shall wanton pleasure thinke to reuell ●ere?
Shall toying apish p●ating Complement
Outface the Muses, teare Apollos lockes,
Intice away the tender brood, with showes
Of empty words, and bubbles vanishing?
Shall shifting sharkes defraud their innocence?
Shall hasty heady Nouices outl●ap their masters lo●,
Presuming on their wit, and vndertake
To read a lecture to their teacher? No.
'Tis well that some haue heretofore for this
Bin made examples of such hastinesse.
Nay let them backward goe, that thus haue runne.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.l: Alas poore childe, I see, he meaneth thee.
Haue pitty on vs great Apoll●s Priest.
Worthy Philoponus intreat Mus●us for my childe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Do'es your childe desire so much?

sp.speaker: Retro.
sp.p: D●g. ris keps. ros. em.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Speake for him good sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: His language is so harsh, that I will speake, if it be but to rid my eares of this preposterous sound. Vene|rable Mus●us. May it please our Lord Apollo, now after two yeers penance to remit the remaining yeer.

sp.speaker: Musaeus.
sp.p: If there be euidence that in this time, he hath retir'd and plyed what formerly he ouerslipped in his rudiments.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: My selfe can partly witnesse that.

sp.speaker: Mus●us.
sp.p: It may be that Apollo will consider him. But let vs hast vp to Per●assus top. The time is come, the Court must now begin.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: My heart is warme with hope to follow them.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: STill I say and sweare vpon my vertues, that you are mistaken. Haue you bin so long my schollar, and are you yet vnacquainted with the Callender of my stipend booke?

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: My bargaine was to allow you fiue crownes a mo|neth, and will you now wire-draw mee to thirteene moneths i'th yeere? When I was Apollos schollar, 〈◊〉 sure Musaeus reckoned but quarterly, 〈◊〉〈◊〉 but twelue moneths i'th yeere.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Apollos Priest must follow his Masters walke, the sunnes yeerely passage through the twelue signes of the Zodiake. I will haue nothing to doe with Astro|nomy.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I, but our Almanackes euery yeere reckon but twelue moneths.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: What dost thou tell me of Almanackes? Vsurer● goe by the Almana●ke. I scorne that griping trade. My moneth is 〈◊〉 weekes ●ust, you may remember them by the changing your shirts, euery fourth shirt determines my pay.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I reckon 〈◊〉 moneth by one shirt.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Who shall be ●udge betweene vs?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Iudge betweene vs? Am not I thine instructer▪ I'le be thy iudge. For euery one of my moneths I te●ch thee a severall straine of Courtesie And so thou hast of me in the yeere, documents accordingly, thir|teene to the dozen.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: My Masters father was a Baker, and therefore he allowes an odde call of courtesie, nea●ly chipt.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Si●a Imp. draw out the Catalogue and number them.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: The first moneth, the Semicircle.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I, with my hat thus. To make iust halfe a circum|ference.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Remember alwaies the drop withall.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: In my motion, my gold hatband must fall downe, thus.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I cry fallings: this is my see, I trow.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: It is an excellent embleme, and signifies that for loue of your friend, you will cast away your gold, and trample it vnder your feet, and that's the reason that Gentlemen now adayes weare their hatbands loose. Register proceed.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: The second moneth the Calue-claspe.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Performe it with Imp. that I may view you the better. Doe you remember that in arching your arme ouer his shoulder, you must neuer touch his band or garment behinde, but apprehend the calfe with your first touch intirely.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I warrant you, I am old dogge at that.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: If I had knowne you had bin an old dogge, I would not haue trusted you with my Calfe. Ba.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: And before I dismisse the calfe, I giue it the gen|tle nip or prasye thus.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Ba, ba. No Butcher nips a Calfe more neatly in the rumpe.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Which shewes your feruency of loue, that you are loath to be vnclasped from your friends intimity.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I haue it to a hai●e.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Register walke on your monethly pace.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: The third moneth, the gentle shrug.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I must tell you, you haue not got that perfect yet.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Not my shrugge sir? That was my last lesson.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Indeed sir I was by, when Signior Gosso in that action smiled, and asked if you were not lowsie.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: O there's your fault, gentle Gingle. A hundred to one you shrugged but with one shoulder.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I would aduise you hereafter to shrugge by a loo|king-glasse, that you may see after what manner you doe it.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Indeed my looking-glasse is broken with dancing with it in my hand, to marke the postures of my face when I caper'd. But I'le buy another.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Nay, you must buy two, that one may reflect vp|on the other, and then may you at once see your mo|tion in your shrugge both before and behinde.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p:
O excellent! for this double glasse, I'le giue you
a double fee. But, I pray you sir, wherein is my shrug faulty?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: My deare schollar, thou must know, there are di|uers kindes of shrugges, there is the Misers shrugge, and that is accompanied with the scratching of the elbow: the●e is the Beggars shrugge, and that's done with a quicke motion, ●atching, to make a sixe▪ foo|ted bandogge leaue his hold.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: My Master and I act that at home sometimes, when we are loath to part with an old friend, our linnen.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: There is a winter shrugge, and that's performed with the hands insconced in a Muste, & a Foxe-surr'd co● close gi●t. There is a drowsie shrugge, and that sometime befals a gallant, when he has set vp al night at Card●, and sau'd the pulling off his boo●es. This shrugge is commonly performed with displaying out the armes, and yawn●ng with the mouth, which re|presents a kinde of ●ibbards face. And lastly, there is a gentle Italian shrugge.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I pray you sir let me goe with you Let mee see. The Misers shrugge, the winter shrugge, the drowsie shrugge, the lousie shrugge. I shall hardly carry away all these.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Nay, you must carry away none of these. You must leaue them all behinde you. The last and onely gentle shrugge, is your Italian shrugge.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: O the Italian shrugge. The●e 'tis. How's that? I shrugge with desire to learne it.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p:
That shrugge is performed by lifting vp both shoulders exactly together with one vniforme moti|on, somewhat swift, and holding them a while in sus|pence, with the necke somewhat couching, and the chinne thrust out, then the shoulders are to bee let downe againe, as it were by a double pulley, with a
slow motion, which by degrees vanisheth. And if you will accomplish it with a grace, you must all the while cast your eyes into a leering posture.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: O excellent schoole of vertue! But when must I vse this shrugge?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Vpon diuers occurring cases, very vsefully. But especially when you are ask't a question, which you cannot deny with safety, nor assent vnto with honor. In such a tw●-forked dilemma, the shrugge relieues you, and you come off with reputation of wisedome.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: This is an oracle to mee, I pray you expound by example.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Put case that some faire and honourable Lady were mentioned at the Table, and thereupon some busie curious Gentleman should aske you whether there past no tearmes of loue betweene you and her. To deny it, were a derogation from your honou●. To loue or be belou'd is honourable. For you to acknow|ledge it, were perhaps dangerous. Some of the com|pany may be your Riuall, and so rusty iron may leap out of the Ecle-skin, and 'pricke your skinne. Thus Venus may be exchanged for Mars. And of the two, hees the most dangerous companion to a mans na|ked side. One shrugge quits all this, by which you seeme to say, I am not to bee examined vpon this Intergatory. I stand vpon my guard, all arm'd in si|lent wisedome.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Incomparable dogments. Mus●us neuer taught me so good a lesson.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: But high time it is for vs to appeare, the Sessi|on is begunne by this. The villaine Pr●co i● like death, and will spare none. Mee think● I hea●e him 〈◊〉, Captaine Complement appeare. Goe Coach it vp with your Mother. I and my

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: will march vp the hill on foot. Here●ir, I ap|peare sir.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Here sir, at hand. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: SEe how thy soule was sna●'d with sophistry.
No Author here alleadg'd for Hedone,
But quels those poysons with their Antidotes.
Marke Tully in that place doth smoothly pleade
For youthfull Calius, so to palliate
His Clyents true obiected vanities.
There Tully plaid the Lawier for his fee.
Behold him now a sage Philosopher:
Discoursing of Old Age, he there concludes,

l.hi: In voluptatis regno virtutem non posse ●onsistere,

sp.l: That vertue cannot stand where pleasure raignes.
〈◊〉 was a wanton Epicure,
A glosing Poet, but ●wd Moralist:
He sould his soule to Uenus and her sonne,
Such writers we for stile, not matter reade.
Siren from Terence pleads, that in yong men
Deepe quaffing, roating, whooring, is no fault.
Doth not that Poet represent the par●s,
The passions, and seuerall enormities
Of cockering doting fathers, of lewd sonnes,
Of cheating slaues, and cogging parasites?
Thus he describes the vices of those times,
That readers might them hate, no● imitate.
S●, Comique Poets set out drunkennesse
In him that pleads for 〈◊〉, and the while
Doth swagger, stagger, swallow, wallow, snort,
The soule▪ that this picture is, the more
That swinish vice breeds loathing of it selfe.
If I would on a Comique slage display
Vertue in conflict stoutly labouring,
And then in conquest honoured by 〈◊〉;
First would I personate her enemy
In some such busie guiles and forgery,
As this lewd Siren represents to thee.
The rest of Authors, Motiues, Arguments,
Which in that letter you so stood vpon,
Are of no better stampe, as I haue showne.
And can fa●re more at large.
But why should I distrust thy iudgement so?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: You haue, ●udicious Philoponus,
More hardly in the groue, more briefly here,
Dispel'd those mists, which that inchanting witch
Had cast before mine eyes. I see, I see
The light of reason, then eclipsed quite,
But now reuiueing my recouered sight.
O how I loath, and hate that iug●ling hand,
That wrote, or ●each't to me these balefull lines.
What sacrifice to Vertue can I yeeld
More ●r, then thus to teare that ●obe, wherein
That poyson was conuey'd, to be to me
As was the deadly shirt to Hercules?
So would I also her.
sp.stage: He teares thee letter, and stampes on it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
Your best reuenge on her will be henceforth,
No more to speake with her by word or pen, Weomens faire words worke deep with passiue men

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What heaps of thankes owe I, and cannot pay, To such a faithfull other selfe, whose hand Hath reached forth that Ariadnes thred Which me out of this Labyrinth hath led.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Com● let vs vp into Apollos Court. The Session 〈◊〉 long since begunne. There shall you more confirme your resolution, by hea●ing Apollo himself in his iudg|ment seate. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: I Tell thee againe, I haue no great hope of it. You haue suffered so many repulses, that if I were in your case—Where is he. So ho. Come along, mend your pace. What? haue you the gout?

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Alas in foot, and hand too. My father and grand|site had so.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Stand vp for shame. Else how will you appeare in Apollos presence, so much as to present your re|quest.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Well. I'le stretch my limbs so farre, though I bee already tyred with ou● long iourney.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: A long iourney from your Cottage to Apollos Court? when your Tent is fixed but on the other side of the wall. A man may fling a horse loase so farre.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p:
I'le rather bee fed with horse bread, then tra|uaile so farre againe to fetch whitebread. But I
pray you let vs sit downe. I shall talke much wiser, sitting then standing.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Doe not Iudges sit● as now Apollo does there. And I hope they are wiser, then those that stand to heare them.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: I judge standing, that thou hast littl● vnderstan|ding that art such an enemy to standing.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: But sir Drud●, why doe you discourage mee from hope of admittance?

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: The truth is, I see no great reason why you should be admitted. I'me su●e for these seuen yeeres, euery visitation day you haue bin shut out of doores by Mu|saeus as soone as euer hee espyed you lying vpon the bench in Apollos Court. And for the most part, when your name hath bin called aloud by P●co, you haue bin asleepe, and were faine to be ioggd and shak'd a|gaine before you would answer.
Out vpon thee, what art thou in a L●thargy? I thinke thy mother was asleepe when thou wast begotten. So bo. So bo. I tell thee againe, after seuen repulses, why shouldest thou knocke at Apollos gate.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: I dare not knocke at this gate▪ the hammer that hangs on it, is so cold and heauy. And why should I disquiet the Muses with such a noise? Perhaps some of them are asleepe in Apollos lap.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Thou Dormouse, thou liu●st in a perpetuall winter: think'st thou them like to thee?

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: I cannot climbe this hill. I pray fetch Apollo hi|ther. Or be you Apollo.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: What shall Drude be so bold. No. But say what thou canst. Apollo sees and heares all things in all pla|ces.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Why then Apollo. Drudo, I craue admittance.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: What is your clayme?

sp.speaker: Slug
sp.p: I am the top of my kin. I am Slim Slugge, Sluggy Sluggorum.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: What's that to your plea? Are you a kinne to the Muses.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: I haue long prescription time out of time. I haue bin entertain d euermore by some of Apollos prenti|ses. They haue kept me and sed me in their chambers, and hug'd me in their bed. I neuer wanted among them, those that would rather rest with me in a cold morning, then dance after the Muses pipe with be|num'd hands and chattering teeth.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: All Wines haue some ●ees,
All Bee-hiues some D●oanes.
Think'st thou that such prescription shall get thee ad|mittance?

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: I am weary of sitting. I thinke it were better for me to lye downe vpon this banke. I shall talke much wiser yet when my head lyes lower then my heeles, for then all my spirits and wi●s sinke downe into my braine. So ●'le tell thee now what learn'd counsaile I gaue to a young schollar, when he told me that his Master chid him for keeping his bed. Why (quoth I to him) then answer your Master, I pray you sin, would you haue me ●ll my bed? your law, that you giue vs, is, Nil dabis, aut vendes.—

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Very learnedly applyed to the purpose.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: When I read lecture to my auditors.—

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Surely then thou giu'st a deepe nod at euery s● point.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: I inioyne them, Sell your Bookes, sell your Inke|hornes, sell your Candlestickes, sell your Points, but neuer sell your beds. The bed is the seate and throne of a schollar. For contemplation requires quietnesse. And when is a man more quiet, then when he is in 〈◊〉 bed? Ergo.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Spoken like a Philosopher, but of the Epicures sect.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Nay you shall haue Philosophy vp to the elbowes. The bed is the beginning and end of a man. When we come into the world, are not our Mothers said to be brought to bed? When we dye, are not we on our death bed? Whil'st we liue, when are we more inno|cent then when we are asleepe in our bed? then wee thinke no body any hurt. When are mischiefes done by men, but when they are awake, and imploy them|selues most busily? Ergo.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: It seemes so by thee, for thou art seldome awake thus long, but to doe some such mischiefe at to talke in this manner.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: The best Philosophers haue said, and I haue heard it in Apollos schoole. Motus fit propter quietem. Nature intends motion, that it may attaine rest. And all schollars know, that what is desired, as the end, is bet|ter then that, which is ordained as the meanes to it.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Nay siria, the best of them say, that motion is better then rest. For the heauens moue continually, and the earth, which is the dregs of the world, that rests, and slugs like thee. The day is for labour, and the night for rest. And I hope the day is farre better then the night. Ergo.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Well. I haue all the earth on my side: I'me safe e|nough. Goe you and dance after the starres. I'le hold my rest here.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Enough of this Philosophy. Thou lolling lubber, lasie Bough, get vp, Rise old huncks, rise drunken Beare, or I'le goe in without thee.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: A Beare? no. I'me a worthier beast, by my hardly rising. I am like an Elephant.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: I wood thou hadst a Castle vpon thy backe, then I wood hang thee out for a signe, and it should bee call'd the drowsie Inne. Come away, your name it call'd ere this at the Session, and Prac● woon't sa|uour you. You will be in, forty Markes in issues.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: My turne is alwayes last. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: S●spbu. Scopas. Come away with the Cull●. Lay that Carpet smoother. When were these Cushions brusht. Sirra. ha?

sp.speaker: Scop.
sp.p: I haue heard say, that too much brushing will we are them out.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Thou Lozell. Hath Slugge infected you? Why doe you giue such kinde entertainement to that cob|webbe?

sp.speaker: Scop.
sp.p: It shall haue Tom Drums entertainement. A flap with a Foxe tayle.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p:
For the preparing this Iudgement seate. I pro|nounce iudgement of banishment against all pre|sumptuous Cobwebbes. The Court will rise, and
come vpon vs ere we are aware. Scopas goe see how forward they are, and bring away the Frankinsence.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: VVHere are they, tha●ay that Iudio is the Canker of the schoole? I haue pro|nounced a knocking Apology before Apollo and all his Court.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: What, nimble Ludio, is the Session so farre on?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Vnto thee, O Thur●er, I am the Nuntio, to tell thee, that Apollo and his Actors are by this time come to Actus quintus, Scena qua● a. Pr●o told me they will all com● downe hither to Act Scen●●ima.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: I shall be ready for them. But I pr●, I●dio, how did Mistresse Gingle behaue her selfe?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: She neue●●sed crying out to Apollo, O the ●e|nerous Captaine Complement! O that he may bold ●is ●e|nement. Apollo himsel● was faine to command her silence.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Did not Siren creepe into the soules of the au|ditory?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: My friend Siren slid on smoothly, like my feete vpon the ice. I thinke shee has vnbent Apollos bow. She will haue a good day of it, I hope. Yong Gingle in his triall stood much vpon his gentry, and carried himselfe like a fine dancing Courtier. When I heard Slugge call'd, I thought we should tarry long, and so away came peelegarlicke Ludio, to get him a roome before hand here.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: But thou tellest me nothing all this while of thy owne tryall. Were you not put to it shrewdly?

sp.speaker: Ludio
sp.p: I trow I put Apollo and all his Muses to it. There can no sentence passe against me. My defence was so strong and vnanswerable.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: I am sorry that my office called mee away from hearing you, will you doe mee the honour to impart to me some of your discourse?

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: I haue it here ●grossed and recorded.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: I wonder how you could borrow so much time from play, as to compose so large a declaration?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: I haue a ●end in a corner, I teach him the knacks of gaining, how to cut a bum card, how to helpe a dye, and such like, and he in kinde requi●all has drawne an Apology for me in forme of Law, ac|cording to the stile or Apollos Court.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Could you before all them pronounce it lustily, as if it had bin your owne making?

sp.speaker: Lud●o
sp.p: I haue a certaine vertue called audacity. I hat did beare me our where my wit or memory failed.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: I ●ng to heare some of it. Can you say it?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: So, ●o: As we doe our lessons, with a casting a leere eye sometime vpon my paper.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: It is l●ge. I will n●〈◊〉●le thee to say it ouer. Onely reade I pray you some of the principall points.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: I tell thee here be aboue a dozen of points. You sh●l haue a touch of the fore-point thus.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: I haue knowne the time when you haue had nei|ther fore not ●d point, when you haue return'd from ●purne point.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p:
First, I look't grauely like Cato, and withall, cheerefully like Pu●rilis And then to show what con|fidence I had in my cause, I strok't vp my foretop with the combe of my finders thus. My sister had
sprinckled it with rose water, and my lips too, to make my Rhetoricke the sweeter.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: No doubt rose water added a sweet sound to your words.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Then I made ob●ysance thrice, with a nimble low stoope which I learn't when we plaid at Ducke Fryer. Then 〈◊〉●m, ●em to cleare my voice, and to prouoke the Auditory to answer mee with their gentle expectation.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Here is a large Entry to a low house.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Then displaying my naked protesting hands, I said. O thou louely Lord of learning, beauteous, bounteous Apollo.
sp.l: O thou euer mouing Phoebus,
Whose golden lockes and siluer bow,
Embellish heauen and earth below.
O yee assistant sisters ●ne,
Attend this iust de●ence of mine.
sp.p: What law, what iustice, what reason can pronounce a gainst Ludio the sentence of expulsion? Is not Apollos Schoole stiled ladus literarius. Is it not Sc●ola from 〈◊〉 〈◊〉〈◊〉 otium, remedy, play, relaxation? What talke we of Apollos Court. The whole world is made free of Ludios Trade, and dances after his pipe.

What is our life but a game, wherein some winne, some lose, some idly looke on, some haue good fortune, and will not be known of their winnings, others haue bad lucke, and curse their starres and fates; Some cheate and ●ke, and others are befooled?
All Dame Natures lumpe is a true Ludio. If you banish Ludio, you must banish the heauens and elements.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: What? is this brat become a Philosopher?

sp.speaker: Ludis.
sp.p:
The highest fixed starres, what doe they all the yeere but dan●e their measures, and kee● there●
their stately distances, and, to shew their mirth and wantonnesse, they with their glaring eyes twinckle on their spectators. The Planets haue variety of dances, sometime graue Pauins, otherwhile ●mble G●rds.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: ●e Sellingers round.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Now a pace forward, now retyring backward.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Like a new Corranto.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: What sayest thou Thuriger? did not I play the A|stronomer well?

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Better then sixteene Almanac●e-makers, with all their Sextile aspects, and siery triplicities.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: But now sir here was I put to my trumpes, when I came to bring in our Lord Phoebus himselfe for an example, in my owne defence, in his owne presence. Th●●fore I begun with c●auing pardon. O Maie|s● Lord of the day, Moderator of the yeere, R●ng-leader of all the glittering lampes; giue poore Ludio leaue to shew that in the worke o● thy bright Regiment, thou canst not be without him. Dost thou not all the yeere long recreate thy selfe by taking the ayre about the hill of heauen in thy guilded Caroch, drawne with foure prancing horses?

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Some mortals now adaies haue in their Coach more horses then Don▪ P●oebus.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: In this thy yeerly iourney thou art so frolicke e|uery spring, that thou giuest our mother earth a greene ●owne.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.l: That is (our Virgins say)
A pretty kinde of play.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: And in thy iournall circle when thou comest and goest, euery day and night, mee thinkes thou playest at 〈◊〉▪ peepe, and Hide and seeke.
sp.l: All night it our all hid. But in the day
We seeke about. For what, say I, but play?

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: O Impudency! How durst thou base slea, skippe thus high into Apollos face. Didst thou not feare to be pierced through with the least dart of his beames?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: The truth is, one of Apollos learned Councell had like to pull'd me downe, when he told me that it was against law to produce the Iudge for a witnesse. Else I had gone on to alledge his playing at Quoits with Cy|parissus.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: He would haue cond you small thanke for that. But, how did our Lord Apollo looke vpon you all this while?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Me thought hee put his hand toward his quiuer, and withall, shaked his golden lockes. Then thought I, 'twas time for me to glide downe lower, and talke of Lady Lu●a. Mistresse Moone (quoth I) what is her monethly taske, but to runne a gossipping through|out all the twelue signes in the high street of the Zo|diacke?.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: The signe of the Ram, the Bull: the Lion, and the rest, they are Tauernes set vp by Bacchus, for the gods to feast in. Are they not?.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: She knocks at euery doore, & tarryes two daies at the least in each of those houses. And as the Sunne courts her, shee makes cur●es in her round walke, sometimes ba●fully putting on her Maske.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: That is in coniunction.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Otherwhile she shewes her halfe face very de|murely.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Halfe moone; like my cheese.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: And after that appeares her broad Owles face, to allure Endymion to be in loue with her.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: The Shepheard with the bu●h of thornes has preuented sleepy Endymion, and gotten vp thit● before him.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: The waues in the sea, what doe they, but play at trusse and leapsrogge on one anothers backe? The winds in the are performe one perpetuall exercise, and that is blow-point.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Sometimes they blowest the points of ●ee|ples, and this is a very high point, worth conside|ration.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: They play very merrily: and therefore wee often heare them ●g and whis●le.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Leaue o● now your rehearsall Ludio. Why pr●|ted you of the starres and winde●? What's this to you, and to those creatures that haue bound them|selues to the schoole trade? Doe the Mules play?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Yes vndoubtedly, the Nine Muses play at Nine|holes: euery Muse hath her hole

sp.speaker: T●r.
sp.p: Yes, and euery Hate hath her Muse. But what then becomea o● the 〈◊〉 h●e?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: That's a great one 〈◊〉Apollo their Master and ours.

sp.speaker: Pr●co.
sp.p: Thinkst t●ou, that Apollo will bee mooued with these reasons, to let such a ve●mine harbour in the pi|geon house 〈◊〉 the M●?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Doe ●u thinke that I will sucke their egges? Doe I looke lik● a su●〈◊〉? I am sure the Auditory did entertaine 〈◊〉 speech 〈◊〉 th● si●ne of approba|tion▪ hum, hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: That 〈◊〉〈◊〉 but the yo●er sort, and those that stood at the lower end of the Session hall.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: I am much 〈◊〉●aken if Apollo himselfe did not in the end hum and 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: I thinke rather Apollo frown'd on you.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.p: I thinke rather that Mercury frowned on me.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Why Mercury? he is not there.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p:
I'le tell thee, honest Thuriger, Whilst I was in
the heare of my pleading, some Villaine, borne vnder the Planet Mercury, nims away my sachell that lay behinde me.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: What losse suffered you in that vessell?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: The Shipwracke of all my best houshold-stuffe, and tooles of my trade. What thinke you, Thuriger, does this forebode ill lucke to me?.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: I thinke it had bin better lucke, if you had bin rob'd of those Commodities seuen yeeres agoe. But see yonder comes my Scopas.

sp.speaker: Scopas.
sp.p: THey are comming hard by. Here is the fran|kinsence. Put it in your selfe.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: This fire is almost out, stirre it vp.

sp.speaker: Scopa●.
sp.p: Laurell wood doth soone spend.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.l: Apollos iudgement seate
Makes all things pure and neat. Apollos iudgment, &c.

div.head: Actus quintus. Scena sex● et vltima.
div.stage: Thuriger. Scopas. Drudo. Lauri●er. Pr●co. Musaeus. Clio. Euterpe. Philo●onus. Am●s. Siren. Ludio▪ Im|plement. Slugge. Geron. Retro. N●ce.

sp.speaker: Lauriger.
sp.p: COme along, come on in ranke.

sp.speaker: Pr●co.
sp.p: On afore, On afore▪ Hold vp the booke. Giue roome, roome, more roome.

sp.speaker: Drudo.
sp.p: We must haue roome, more then the whole Ci|ty of Rome.
Clio, you must sit down, and you E●erpe. Musaeus croues your assistance.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: P●o doe your office.

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: Silentium: et Tace●e. Our Lord Apollo by his de|puted Iudge, the venerable Musaeus, doth command silence, and chargeth all, whom it may concerne, to attend the Court, and heare the charge

sp.speaker: M●.
sp.l: Ou● great Apollos Pallace seemeth like
A spacious gard'n set with choysest flowers,
Wherein creepe vp by small vnleene degrees
Vnu●ull, hurt●ull, and vnsauory weedes;
Which ouergrow and choake the better plant●,
And make the tender flowers to hang the head.
Himselfe chiefe Gardner hath, from yonder top
Of this our sacred ●ll, euen now ●view'd
All that his herbage, and with cutious eye
Discerned and designed by his doome,
What must be cherisht, and what weeded out.
Me, his vnworthy seruant, he appoints,
As vnder-gardiner, with that wholesome hooke.
To check, or nip, or toot vp what he dam'd.
〈◊〉 by oracle he did vnfold,
What lot attends on euery name inrold.
Pr●co, read the Record, and cite the names.

sp.speaker: Pr●o.
sp.p: Memorandum. On Apollos Shroueday, being the eight and twentieth of Aquarius, in the great hall of the westerne top of Par●assus. Our soueraigne Lord Apollo sitting in person vpon oyer and terminer, after full hearing of all parties, did then and there adou● the Court, to be presently continued at the foote of the said h●, vnder the Lawrell, at the Temple gate, and to be there consummate by his reuerend Iudge Musaeus.
The names of the parties sentenced by Apollo.
Siren,the first is Siren. Appeare Siren Spinster.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: She spinnes nothing but spiders webbes, to catch flyes.

sp.speaker: ●aur.
sp.p: Siren come out What doe you lu●ke? Appeare in your likenesse, and heare your doome.

sp.speaker: Pr●co.
sp.p: Vous ●uez Si●.

sp.speaker: Siren.
sp.p: I haue a great deale more to say for myselfe, and for my Lady Hedone. I hope, I shall be heard.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: You would faine be heard; because you thinke your tongue inchants. There is no pleading now. A|pollos doome is past.

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: You must heare the Iudge, or else bee prest to death presently.

sp.speaker: Musaeus.
sp.p: Siren, then thus for Siren.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Record the sentence Praeco.

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: My penne is as nimble as your tongue.

sp.speaker: Musaeu●.
sp.p: Siren must first be sea●cht.

sp.speaker: S●.
sp.p: Sacred dispencer of Apollos iustice, I hope you will not suffer a poore Nimp● to be vsed so immodest|ly. If I must be ransa●, I p●y you let it be done by a Iury of Muses. The three Graces, empanneld with them, will make vp the whole number of twelue good weomen, and true.

sp.speaker: C●o.
sp.l: If I be made fore-woman of your iury,
You shall be doom'd by iustice, not by fury.

sp.speaker: ●rpe.
sp.l: We Mus● enuy no man,
Much lesse will wrong a woman.

sp.speaker: Musaeus.
sp.p: Wee shall not need to trouble you noble Clio▪ nor you sweet Euterpe. This search is onely of her vp|per garment. I auriger lift vp ●er va●le.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Come, I must loue, and court thee now.

sp.speaker: Drudo.
sp.p: O vgly a filthy fi●es taile.

sp.speaker: Musaeus.
sp.p: Pull off her head of yallow lockes.

sp.speaker: Drudo.
sp.p: O blacke b●stles. O nasty Vermine!

sp.speaker: Musaeus.
sp.p: This seeming glosing Nimph is nothing else, but an vgly sea▪ Monster. She is dam'd to returne to the sea, and there to be tossed, and do●ssed, together with S●ylla, that monstrous shame of nature. But, be|fore you ●icke her out, let her take a message to car|ry to Dame Hed●e, if ere they meete againe. That is, that Hedone shall euer vnseparably bee manacled to Lupe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: O iust d●ome, that pleasure shall bee alwaies 〈◊〉 to paine. Which also this false Siren prooues. ●irst, a face see●ing faire to meet with: but if you further goe, turpem 〈◊〉 in pisc● mul● formos● superne.

sp.speaker: Laur. Drudo. Pr●co. Philop Omnes.
sp.p: Out with her.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I will haue one kick more at her for inueigling me: Out Bitch.—Exit Siren.

sp.speaker: Mus●us.
sp.p: On Pr●co. Who is next?

sp.speaker: Pr●o.
sp.p: The next is Ludio. Appeare Ludio Gamester. Vous b●uez Ludi●.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Here appeares poore banckrout Ludio. I hau● suffered losses by misfo●tune.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What misfortune? fire? or theeues?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: I sir. Theeues, they haue rob'd mee of all my brass● coine, and vnbound paper bookes. I must set vp with a new stocke.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: The 〈◊〉 meanes his cards and counters.

sp.speaker: Mus●us.
sp.p:
Thou bold else, that canst ●ot at thy triall for
get thy play. Apollo fit● thee with a doome, that thou shalt pl●y vncessantly.

sp.speaker: Ludio
sp.p: I'me glad of that A 〈◊〉 play-day.

sp.speaker: Mus●us.
sp.p: And thou sh●lt ●ue fifty 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: So much good company doe● the b●tter.

sp.speaker: Mus●us.
sp.p: They are the fi●ty daughte●s of 〈◊〉; whose play is still to fetch and fetch water in a sieue. Thou must play still at dice.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: At dice? that's well▪ I●e che●te all those fifty wenches.

sp.speaker: Mus●us.
sp.p: But thus. Thy dice 〈◊〉 must put into a bot|tomlesse boxe. So, when 〈◊〉 throwest, they fall to the ground: and thou must t●ke them vp: they fall a|gaine, thou 〈◊〉 againe. Thi●〈◊〉 the M●ll h●e|ring, wherein thou must 〈◊〉●und eternally.

sp.speaker: ●il.
sp.p: He that would finde Lu●, must seeke ●im at the signe of the Labour in va●e.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: O would I had s●died when I played▪ rather then thus to play at lost labour 〈◊〉. Exit.

sp.speaker: Praec●.
sp.p: Mistresse Indi●ence 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Blinde fortune h●th quit he● o● that; but shee i● true to her name 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: Mistresse 〈◊〉 Gin●le. Spi●ster.

sp.speaker: Dr●do.
sp.p: All the wooll and fl●xe, t●at 〈◊〉 she spunne, I will eate and feare no choaking.

sp.speaker: Mus●us.
sp.p: Doth she not appeare?

sp.speaker: Drudo.
sp.p: She scowred awa● in her Coach with her sonne, and said she would dwell no longer in Thess●ly, i● her sones best instructor be not suffered here. And a● she fled, her Coach oue●ned.

sp.speaker: Mus●us.
sp.p: Let her foure w●eeles carry Apollos curse with her, that none of her kindred shall euer get aboue the petty forme of Apollos schoole. Passe o●〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Pr●co.
sp.p: Io●n Gingle, Gentleman Woo'd-be.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Apollo pronounceth that his lot must be, before he be forty yeeres old, to spend all his fiue Mannors vpon the fiue Sences: Except the Mansion house of ●oolingham, which is intailed to the heires of his bo|dy wo●fully begotten.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: For ●y part I will not be of counsell to cut off th● en●aile.

sp.speaker: Pr●co.
sp.p: Complement, p●etended Captaine, alias Captaine Comp. Fashion●nger.

sp.speaker: Drudo.
sp.p: He is ●led, ●s ●heare.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Fled with 〈◊〉 witnesse. For he flew like a bird vp in the aire.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Then has he sau'd vs a labour. For Apollo had doom'd him to be blowne vp with Vulcans bellow● into the middle Region of the ayre.

sp.speaker: L●r.
sp.p: The boyes in the outer-court of Apollos Pallace, when they 〈◊〉 by Mistresse Gingles discontent, that the Captaine was like to be banished, they pre|uented execution, by tying squibs to his ●kirts; which being fired, this light ●usball mounted vp into the ay● as high as a ●arke.

sp.speaker: ●hil.
sp.p: One boy said, that this was the Captaines losty cap●ring tricke.

sp.speaker: Drudo.
sp.p: And whither did this whi●le winde carry him?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Who knowes? But most do● thinke to the Iland of Coxcombria, a place thicke impeopled with such riff●●affe.

sp.speaker: Pr●co.
sp.p: Iacke Implement, Page to the aforesaid Comple|ment. Vous hauez Implement.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Here sir, at hand. I pray you Master Musaeu● be good to a poore Page. I had but a hard seruice vnder him My bed and board was sc●rce to the mountenance of a water-Spanniell. I would saine goe to schoole a|gain●.

How right this boy meetes with Apollos〈◊〉 Thy lot i● for the schoole againe: but there for one whole yeere thou must smooth out the dogs care● of all thy fellowes bookes; And vow to ply thy booke as nimbly as euer thou didst thy Maste● Ap●ry, or the hauty vaulting horse.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I vow, and will. Elle let mee ●ide our blinde horse that kickes vs on the back●.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: What Slugge, could you not come along with vs? You must be lagge. An houre will s●arce serue you, though your iourney be short, and downe th● hill.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Soft fire, 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Musaeus
sp.p: The next name 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Answer to your name.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: He will not answer, vnlesse you giue him all his titles. 〈◊〉〈◊〉. Sl●e of Slugge-ha●l.

sp.speaker: Pr●co.
sp.p: Why then Slim Slugge, 〈◊〉 Sluggorum, Slug● of Slugge-hall, S●eper.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Pr●co.
sp.p: Vous hau●z Slugge. Stand forth and attend the sentence.

sp.speaker: Mus●us.
sp.p: Thou night-bird, in whose ●sly nest all Bookes and Inkehornes, and all things else are m●ul|dy, but thy bed. Yet there dost thou pigge in, and pigge out, without molesting the feathers by con|cussion.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Stand vpright, and leaue thy yawning.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Thou that neuer mayest infect the Muses habita|tion, Apollo doth banish thee into Lubberland.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Lubberland? I'me glad of that. I shall earne my fourteene pence a day there by sno●ting. But who shll carry me th●ther?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Nay, you must foot it thither, there lyes the ma●ow of your punishment.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: O that I had Tom Co●ats euerlasting shooes! But ho which is the way to Lubberland? Has none of you bin 〈◊〉 Will y●u goe with mee? will you in the frize coate? It is a fine Country. There are riuers of Mu kad●e, and bridges of Brawne, parkes of Ven●▪ son Pasties, paled about with puddings and sausages. H●y for our towne, hey for Lubberland.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: 〈◊〉, I thinke thou dr●amest of Lubberland. Why d● not y●u p●sse on?
Yon●No●ice, Apprentice.

sp.speaker: No●ice.
sp.p: Here. I p●ay sir, saue me: I'le get my Mothe● to end y●. 〈◊〉〈◊〉 a couple of Capon●.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: 〈◊〉〈◊〉〈◊〉 fre● man, and thy follies come of simple 〈◊〉〈◊〉, and are not de●pely rooted in thee, there is hope o● thy 〈◊〉. ●or three yee●es thou shalt p●y but an houre in the weeke, and all thy scho●le 〈◊〉〈◊〉〈◊〉 fr●m the presence and ●dance of Ph●onus. Obseru● and imitate his pam|●ll diligenc●: so shalt thou get the Muses loue, and ●ord Apollo fau●ur.

sp.speaker: No●.
sp.p: Thankes, 〈◊〉▪ thankes to him, and thee for this your 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: G●on.
sp.p: Good your Wo●ship, be good to my sonne, hi● Mother will runne 〈◊〉 for gri●.

sp.speaker: M●s.
sp.p: Thy sonn●▪ Come hither Retro.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Mercy sir, mercy.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p:
Apollo ha● acc●pted thy submission, and cu● o● the third yeer● of thy punishment. Ari●e, and s●ew
thy face, Thy tongue may now runne right, & speake as others doe. You may be a forward childe.

sp.speaker: Retro.
sp.p: Thankes, O most forward thankes, for the resto|ring of my distorted limbes and tongue.
Retiring Crabbe farewell. Welcome humane pace.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: But see thou holdst the schollars euen path, nor st●iding f●st, nor wandr●ng from the way.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: I hankes sacred Priest I shall bring ●y wife ioy|full newes.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Now is Apollos garden weeded quite,
Compos'd in order, swept, and cleanly dight.
Now may each tender plant, and goodly flowre
Grow vp, and th●e, by heauens assisting power.
Pr●co, dissolue the Session.

sp.speaker: Pr●co.
sp.p: Oyez, Our soueraigne Lord Apollo, hauing held and finished his Visitation, dischargeth all suiters, par|ties, and homagers from their attendance in this place; and licenseth all his subiects and seruants, to depa●t to their seuer all habitations.

sp.speaker: Clio.
sp.l: It ioyes my heart, that we poore Mus●s,
Now haue redresse of our abuses.

sp.speaker: Euterpe.
sp.l: Before alas I mou●nd and wept:
But now I ioy: our schoole is swept.,

lg.l: Accept (we pray) our hasty huddled games;
Who thus imploy our parts, ou● paines most gl●dly,
In hope to please our Mother Towne of Ha●y.
And thus with this our homely shrouing dish,
A merry Shrou●tide to you all we w●h.
T●s late▪ Me thinkes I spye some dro●ie head,
Whose yawning, nodding toles a peal● to bed▪
If any such be here, wee'le take them n●pping,
And all ●o boxe their eares with loud hand-clapping.
